awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Physics and Astronomy Research at Rutgers
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the continuation of the Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) site in the Department of Physics and Astronomy at Rutgers, the State University of New Jersey. Nine students per summer will be brought to Rutgers for ten weeks each, during which they will engage in forefront research in astronomy, high-energy and nuclear physics, condensed matter physics, and physics education. The students will also engage in a program of field trips and professional development activities that educate them about the conduct of research and arm them with the information and tools they need to define and achieve their educational and professional goals. The award will promote the progress of science in the multiple areas from which research projects are drawn, and will support the education and training of 27 students-- many from underrepresented backgrounds and/or institutions with limited research opportunities-- thereby broadening participation in the physics and astronomy communities and the STEM workforce.

To achieve its goals, the REU site will provide a mixture of formal and informal settings in which participating students will interact with each other, with their faculty mentors and assigned graduate student "near-peer" mentors, with Rutgers undergraduate physics and astronomy majors, and with a diverse co-residential peer group from outside Rutgers working in completely different STEM fields. Faculty mentors include multiple APS Fellows and NSF CAREER award winners and are a vibrant, collegial, intellectually diverse, and well-funded set of scientist-educators with exciting research programs and excellent records of working with undergraduates. Students will live and socialize with peers in the Rutgers Research in Science and Engineering (RiSE) program, a key organizational partner. Relative to the previous site award, the renewal award will innovate by introducing mentorship training, flexible supervisory arrangements, physics education research opportunities, and program assessment featuring national benchmarking and external evaluation.

por.por_cntn:
This award supported the renewal of a Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site at Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey, which offered summer research projects in astronomy, particle physics, and nanophysics to a total of 27 students from across the U.S. and its territories from 2016 through 2018. Participants were selected on the basis of transcripts, personal statements, and recommendation letters from a pool of 992 applicants; residential and social activities were coordinated with the multi-disciplinary Research Intensive Summer Experience (RISE) program at Rutgers. As an indication of the REU program's intellectual merit, 22 of the 27 participating students presented the results of their research at professional conferences (e.g., sponsored by the American Astronomical Society or the American Physical Society) after the end of the summer, two more presented their results at undergraduate research conferences, and one student (co-)authored a total of four papers on their research in nuclear physics. The broader impacts of the award were chiefly related to the research training and professional development of the participating students. Each REU student was supported not only by a faculty research mentor, but also by a designated graduate student "near-peer mentor." All-day field trips to the Rose Center for Earth and Space at the American Museum of Natural History, the IBM Thomas J. Watson Research Center, and Brookhaven National Laboratory supplemented a program of weekly workshops and discussions (on topics ranging from the responsible conduct of research to careers in and beyond physics and astronomy), along with demonstration-driven sessions to help prepare students for the physics GRE subject test. As of April 2023, 21 of the 27 REU participants from 2016-18 had matriculated in graduate school in physics, astronomy, or a related field. The demographics of its participants (48% women, 26% African American, Hispanic American, or Native American, and only 41% from "R1" research universities) mean that the REU program has effectively contributed to the broadening of participation in research by members of underrepresented groups.

Funds remaining at the end of the original grant period were used to help support the participation of (a) four RISE students doing research in physics and materials science in summers 2019 and 2020, and (b) two full cohorts of REU students in summers 2021 and 2022 following the site's renewal (award AST-2050950; PI Geraldine Cochran).
